shot.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: an act of firing a gun
shot.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: He pulled out his rifle and fired three shots.
She was killed by a single shot to the head.
shot.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the sound of a gun being fired
shot.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Where were you when you heard the shot?
shot.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: someone who is good, bad etc at shooting
shot.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Sergeant Cooper is an excellent shot.
shot.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: small metal balls that are shot, many at a time, from a shotgun
shot.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: large metal balls that are shot from a cannon
shot.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: an attempt in sport to throw, kick, or hit the ball towards the place where you can get a point
shot.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Shaw took a shot at the goal from the halfway line, but missed.
shot.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: We hired a photographer to take some publicity shots.
action shots of football players  (=ones taken of people while they are moving)
a close-up shot of a demonstrator being beaten by a policeman
I managed to get some good shots of the carnival.
shot.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: the view of something in a film or television programme that is produced by having the camera in a particular position
shot.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: In the opening shot, we see Travolta’s feet walking down the sidewalk.
shot.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: an attempt to do something or achieve something, especially something difficult
shot.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: I decided to have a shot at decorating the house myself.
I didn’t think I had much chance of winning the race, but I thought I’d give it a shot (=try to do it).
The network finally gave Keaton a shot at presenting his own show.
This is her first shot at directing a play.
If Lewis won his next fight, he would be guaranteed a shot at the title (=chance to win the title).
shot.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: a remark that is intended to criticize or hurt someone
shot.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: I’m not going to sit here listening to you two take shots at each other all night.
She couldn’t resist a parting shot (=one that you make just before you leave) – ‘And you were a lousy lover!’
That was a cheap shot (=one that is unfair and unreasonable)!
shot.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: a small amount of a strong alcoholic drink
shot.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: a shot glass (=a small glass for strong alcoholic drinks)
shot.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: an injection of a drug  (=when it is put into the body with a needle)
shot.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: Have you had your typhoid and cholera shots?
shot.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: a heavy metal ball that competitors try to throw as far as possible in the sport of shot put
shot.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: The passenger in the car fired three shots.
Someone took a shot at her, but missed.
The shot hit the burglar in the chest and killed him instantly.
The first shot missed my head by inches.
A pistol shot rang out in the darkness.
He died from a single shot to his heart.
It wasn’t clear who had fired the fatal shot.
Police fired warning shots into the air.
It was difficult to get a good shot in the dense forest.
He fired off a volley of shots from his rifle.
shot.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: in bad condition because of being used too much or treated badly
shot.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: My nerves were shot to pieces after my driving test.
shot.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the past tense and past participle of shoot
